items.title: Drop Python 2.7 support
items.body: Python 2.7 is now EoL by the upstream python community. It's time to discuss dropping python 2.7 support from testtools. My feeling is we should push out a release soon with current master (and any other necessary improvements) and document that as the last release supporting python 2.7. Then remove 2.7 support from master so it's staged for the next release.

items.title: Deprecate and drop Python 3.4 support
items.body: Python 3.4 was marked as EoL in March 2019 (https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0429/#id4 ) and has no upstream support anymore. It also accounts for < 1% of our current pypi downloads. We should mark python 3.4 support as deprecated and stop testing it a release or 2 after that deprecation is announced.

items.title: Remove use of obsolete unittest2
items.body:
From the unittest2 PyPI page:

> unittest2 is a backport of the new features added to the unittest testing framework in Python 2.7 and onwards.

testtools no longer supports Python <2.7 so there is no reason to use the backport unittest2 module.  Instead, the standard library unittest module can be used.

This would be great since unittest2 is old, crufty, and essentially unmaintained.

items.title: Test streams are uselessly verbose
items.body:
I have an issue with testrepository, where test repositories are very big (around the 25M+). I looked at the content, and the vast majority is made of stuff like this: 

Content-Type: text/plain;charset=utf8
pythonlogging:'something'
0

My test suite used a lot of LoggerFixture, and I believe that's the cause of it. But it seems I get an event even if the logger doesn't get anything, which seems like a waste. We shouldn't add the test details if there isn't any data to log.

I'm opening the issue in testtools because I think it's where I can fix it.

items.title: Don't use "unittest2" for Python 3
items.body:
testtools require unittest2 for testing, but unittest2 "is no longer needed" for Python 3 (quoted from https://pypi.python.org/pypi/unittest2). Please update requirements file to conditionally require unittest2 only for older Python version.

Each additional package makes distribution maintainers life more complicated, since they have to maintain yet another package even if the distribution only includes Python 3.5 or even 3.6.

Thanks.

items.title: Don't use "traceback2" for CPython >= 3.5
items.body:
traceback2 is a backport of the traceback module of python 3.5 so there is no need for it in Python >= 3.5. Please change the requirements file and the import to conditionally require unittest2 only for older Python version.

Each additional package makes distribution maintainers life more complicated, since they have to maintain yet another package even if the distribution only includes Python 3.5 or even 3.6.

Thanks.

items.title: Contains(List) matcher
items.body:
Would it make sense to add a `ContainsList` matcher similar to `ContainsDict`? I have a situation where I want to check if an element in the list conforms to a matcher which doesn't seem to be possible with current stock matchers. For example `ContainsList` can be used as
```python
>>> ContainsList([MatchesDict({"a": "b"})]).match([{"a": "b"}, {"b": "c"}])
None
``` 
I can't use `MatchesListWise` as I am concerned only about one element in the list. Maybe a better alternative would be `Contains` taking a matcher? So above can be written as
```python
>>> Contains(MatchesDict({"a": "b"})).match([{"a": "b"}, {"b": "c"}])
None
```

items.title: TypeError: CaptureTwistedLogs puts strings into details
items.body:
Using testtools 2.1.0 with Python 3.5.1 on Ubuntu 16.04 I observe:

``` python
>>> from testtools.twistedsupport import CaptureTwistedLogs
>>> ctl = CaptureTwistedLogs()
>>> ctl.setUp()
>>> ctl.getDetails()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/gavin/.buildout/eggs/testtools-2.1.0-py3.5.egg/testtools/content.py", line 123, in __repr__
    self.content_type, _join_b(self.iter_bytes()))
TypeError: sequence item 0: expected a bytes-like object, str found
```

The iterable of bytes given to `Content` contains a Unicode string:

``` python
>>> ctl.getDetails()["twisted-log"].iter_bytes()
['']
```

I think this is because `CaptureTwistedLogs` is using `StringIO` without encoding:

``` python
    def _setUp(self):
        logs = StringIO()
        full_observer = log.FileLogObserver(logs)
        self.useFixture(_TwistedLogObservers([full_observer.emit]))
        self.addDetail(self.LOG_DETAIL_NAME,
                       Content(UTF8_TEXT, lambda: [logs.getvalue()]))
```

The last line should perhaps be:

``` python
                       Content(UTF8_TEXT, lambda: [logs.getvalue().encode("utf-8")]))
```

items.title: Performance regression with testtools 1.9
items.body:
I realized recently that testr got super slow.

On my repository:

> time testr last
> Ran 5826 tests in 483.814s
> PASSED (id=0, skips=5)

real    1m41.814s
user    1m41.197s
sys 0m0.082s

I tried a bunch of things, and finally: 

> pip install testtools==1.8.0
> 
> time testr last
> Ran 5826 tests in 483.814s
> PASSED (id=0, skips=5)

real    0m20.736s
user    0m20.520s
sys 0m0.051s

So there is a giant performance regression here. I'll try to track it down, but I wanted to file the issue first.

items.title: Example in docstring for `failed` is wrong
items.body:
The example suggests that the matcher you pass in is matched against the exception value:

```
        error = RuntimeError('foo')
        fails_at_runtime = failed(Equals(error))
        deferred = defer.fail(error)
        assert_that(deferred, fails_at_runtime)
```

However, it is actually matched against the failure. You would need to do something like this instead:

```
        error = RuntimeError('foo')
        fails_at_runtime = failed(AfterPreprocessing(lambda f: f.value, Equals(error)))
        deferred = defer.fail(error)
        assert_that(deferred, fails_at_runtime)
```

This is somewhat of an uncomfortable idiom; maybe we need an extra helper here to ease things along?

items.title: self.skip() stopped working with 1.9.0
items.body: We had a test that did self.skip('something') which used to stop the test running and skip just fine with 1.8.1. With 1.9.0 this now raises an exception and reports as a failure.

items.title: assertRaises cannot be used as a context manager
items.body:
Python's unittest.TestCase.assertRaises can be used as a context manager as of Python 2.7. This is nice because it makes the code much easier to read when the call being made in even moderately complicated.

The workaround is to make a new callable that wraps the complicated call, but a context manager would be preferable.

If there is no objection to this feature then I'd be happy to implement it.

items.title: Use six instead of compat
items.body:
In #159 I suggested we drop Python 2.6. We agreed that was a bit risky for now. However, using [six](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/six) instead of testtools.compat is a great idea.

We should:
- Add six as a dependency
- Update code to use six directly instead of compat
- Deprecate compat
- Release
- Delete compat

items.title: Drop Python 2.6 support
items.body:
I propose that:
- the next release be the last release that supports Python 2.6
- we replace `testtools.compat` with a dependency on `six`

items.title: odd setuptools error
items.body:
While running 'python setup.py develop', I get a number of tracebacks, a 100% pegged CPU, and a MemoryError - fun!

Here's how to reproduce:
1. Create a virtualenv for python 3.4.3 (I haven't tested other versions - they may work as well).
   
   ```
   virtualenv -p python3 ve3
   . ve3/bin/activate
   ```
2. Install testtools in 'developer mode':
   
   ```
   python setup.py develop
   ```


The command takes about a minute to complete, and during that time python pegs a CPU core to 100%, and memory usage goes through the roof :(

If `python setup.py develop` isn't supported, we should make it exit immediately with an error. I can't see why we wouldn't support it though, so this is likely 'just a bug'.

items.body: We are rolling back to 1.7 on Mimic; see https://github.com/rackerlabs/mimic/pull/247

items.title: Tries to pull non-existent deps on python3
items.body: The setup.py is declaring some setup and install deps now, including traceback2 and unittest2, which are backports of Python3 modules to Python2. This causes python3 setup.py install to fail.

items.title: Usage not easy
items.body:
Can I use like phpunit ?

usage of phpunit on terminal:
phpunit abc.php

items.title: test attrs are not included in test ids using unittest2 module
items.body:
After merge of following commit:
https://github.com/testing-cabal/testtools/commit/d30ee53f
test attrs dissappeared from test ids.

It was reproduced using testrepository and it's app:
$ testr list-tests

When mentioned commit is reverted it starts work again.

Versions 1.4.0 and 1.5.0 are affected by this.

items.title: subunit.run discover: error: no such option: --list
items.body:
Coincident with the release of 1.2.0, any of our jobs configuring testr with test_list_option=--list are now failing with "subunit.run discover: error: no such option: --list". This seems to be a regression from 1.1.0.

Related bug report at: https://launchpad.net/bugs/1392986

items.title: missing a way to use assertRaises as context manager
items.body:
I think that it would be useful if we can use assertRaises as context manager the same way as in unittest.
That way allows to organize code better (block of code) and store raised exception to variable for further inspection.

items.title: SuccessResultOf matcher for synchronous Deferred testing
skip decorated tests still have setUp and tearDown run around them
items.body:
As shown in the following example (thanks to Jean-Baptiste Lallement): http://paste.ubuntu.com/7627863/, the setUp function is still run when a testcase is decorated with unittest.skip (also with testtools.skip, if that makes a difference). This is contrary to the documentation of @skip in unittest, which say:

"Skipped tests will not have setUp() or tearDown() run around them."

items.title: Reversed order in testtools messages
items.body:
When using an assert such as self.assertEquals(tester(), expected), an error message suggests wrong argument order (as in, not the order in examples in the documentation). Apparently this is confusing enough that OpenStack  opened a family of bugs and filed patches to swap the order in the tests, see:
 https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1277104

If the code is:

```
import testtools

class TestConfigTrueValue(testtools.TestCase):
    def test_testEquals(self):
        reference = "reference-0123456789012345678901234567890123456789"
        def function_under_test():
            return "actual-0123456789012345678901234567890123456789"
        self.assertEquals(function_under_test(), reference)
```

Then running it yields:

```
[zaitcev@guren xxx]$ python3 -c 'import nose; nose.main()'
F
======================================================================
FAIL: testic.TestConfigTrueValue.test_testEquals
----------------------------------------------------------------------
testtools.testresult.real._StringException: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/q/zaitcev/tmp/xxx/testic.py", line 10, in test_testEquals
    self.assertEquals(function_under_test(), reference)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 322, in assertEqual
    self.assertThat(observed, matcher, message)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 417, in assertThat
    raise MismatchError(matchee, matcher, mismatch, verbose)
testtools.matchers._impl.MismatchError: !=:
reference = 'actual-0123456789012345678901234567890123456789'
actual    = 'reference-0123456789012345678901234567890123456789'
```

I'm getting the following traceback.

There's quite a few moving pieces to get this error:
Oracle Enterprise Linux 6u3, python 2.6, testtools 0.9.35.
I'm using Intellij IDEA 13.0.2 on OS X and using remote python and the nosetests runner.

The remote python is executed via ssh with the following command, and noserunner.py is somehow related to TeamcityPlugin framework(?).

my current work around is to use "unittest" runner instead of nosetests.

items.title: Emit proper error message when tests.sort() failed
items.body:
All test cases are sorted by tests.sort()  in testtools/testsuite.py:sorted_tests(). The default sort key is test id, if there is error in test id, TypeError will be raised:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-heatclient/+bug/1243096

We'd better emit proper error message for developer to tell what has happened.

There is a pull request discussion here:
https://github.com/testing-cabal/testtools/pull/52

items.title: Wrong testsRun count in StreamSummary
items.body:
Hello it seems that test count is wrong in StreamSummary. Seems like this line causes the tests to be counted incorrectly: https://github.com/testing-cabal/testtools/blob/master/testtools/testresult/real.py#L740 I guess it should be like: 
        if test_dict['status'] == 'exists':
            return
        self.testsRun += 1
Could you please correct me if I'm wrong?

items.title: Python 3.3 not covered in continuous integration
items.body: https://github.com/testing-cabal/testtools/pull/52 demonstrates that we can accidentally merge code that's not compatible with Python 3.3.  We should fix that.

items.title: AnyMatch isn't exported
items.body:
The following line throws an `ImportError` because _testtools/matchers/**init**.py_ doesn't mention AnyMatch in `__all__`:

``` python
from testtools.matchers import AnyMatch
```

The following is required instead:

``` python
from testtools.matchers._higherorder import AnyMatch
```

That's inconsistent with all the other matchers. This was introduced in revision b3016403, where `AnyMatch` was first defined.

items.title: assertRaises doesn't work if the expected exception has a custom metaclass
items.body: Due to the fact that _is_instance attribute of MatchesException class checks for only type, and not subclasses thereof, all exceptions with custom metaclasses fail the assertRaises test.
